publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: The amorose songes, sonets, and elegies: of M. Alexander Craige, Scoto-Britane
monogr.author: Craig, Alexander

div.head: To CYNTHIA.
div.p: OFfend not, faire Dame; Though the Lines of my Picture change and varie. The World runnes on Wheeles, all things therein mooue without intermission: the solide Earth, the rockes of Caucasus, and the Pyramids of Memphis; both with publike, and their owne motion. Constancie it selfe, is nothing but a languishing and a wauering daunce. I am a Pamphilus, and can not settle my obiect. And since my Loue runnes staggering with a naturall drunkennes, I pray thee (vertuous Cynthia) with patience peruse those Poyems: And (as Aristippus sayd to his man, who by the way was ouer burdened with too much money) carry what you may, and cast away the rest.

closer.signed: Your La. howsoeuer, and wheresoeuer. Ad Cynthiam.

l.hi: Nil forma natura tuae, nihil astra negarunt,
Vna supercilij si tibi dempta nota.
